coredata.dc:title: Effect of low-temperature solvothermal route on controlled growth mechanism of Se rich-ZnSe(en)0.5 templates for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe photoelectrodes
coredata.dc:creator: Patil, Ruturaj P.
Mahadik, Mahadeo A.
Chae, Weon-Sik
Choi, Sun Hee
Jang, Jum Suk
coredata.dc:description: A novel inorganic-organic Se rich-ZnSe(en)0.5 red-brick (ZnSe(en)0.5 RB) was developed on Zinc (Zn) foil through a low-temperature solvothermal synthesis. The structure evolution and growth mechanism of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB were systematically proposed at 80 °C by varying the solvothermal times (2−12 h) . In the reaction system, adsorption of reduced Se2− in presence of ethylenediamine ((en)0.5) induced the red-brick (RB) color to ZnSe(en)0.5. Furthermore, Cd2+ ion-exchange strategy was adopted for converting ZnSe(en)0.5 RB into dual nanoarchitecture photoelectrode (ZnO-Zn1-xCdxSe). The optimum ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode converted from ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 exhibited a photocurrent density of 13.14 mA·cm-2 at -0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl with 237.79 μmol·cm−2 hydrogen evolution over 3 h. The enhanced photocurrent performance was due to the effective light absorption, and the prolonged recombination lifetime. The charge separation and transport mechanisms during photoelectrochemical hydrogen production were also investigated in detail.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A novel inorganic-organic Se rich-ZnSe(en)0.5 red-brick (ZnSe(en)0.5 RB) was developed on Zinc (Zn) foil through a low-temperature solvothermal synthesis. The structure evolution and growth mechanism of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB were systematically proposed at 80 °C by varying the solvothermal times (2−12 h) . In the reaction system, adsorption of reduced Se2− in presence of ethylenediamine ((en)0.5) induced the red-brick (RB) color to ZnSe(en)0.5. Furthermore, Cd2+ ion-exchange strategy was adopted for converting ZnSe(en)0.5 RB into dual nanoarchitecture photoelectrode (ZnO-Zn1-xCdxSe). The optimum ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode converted from ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 exhibited a photocurrent density of 13.14 mA·cm-2 at -0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl with 237.79 μmol·cm−2 hydrogen evolution over 3 h. The enhanced photocurrent performance was due to the effective light absorption, and the prolonged recombination lifetime. The charge separation and transport mechanisms during photoelectrochemical hydrogen production were also investigated in detail.

ce:section.ce:para: To overcome the global environmental pollution and energy crisis issue, the development of alternative green energy resources novel solar energy materials has attracted global interest in the research. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) hydrogen production has received great attention since 1972 owing to the direct conversion of solar energy into hydrogen energy. [1] In the past decade, various kinds of metal chalcogenide nanostructures photocatalyst for hydrogen generation have been developed and investigated in the literature. [2–4] However, metal chalcogenides photocatalyst suffers low activity even under strong illumination due to the rapid electron-hole recombination and serious integral photocorrosion, [5,6] which necessitating the search of novel photocatalyst materials. Additionally, even though traditional metal chalcogenides inorganic material has good optical properties, but it is difficult to control geometrical size shapes compared to the organic compound. Therefore, engineering of semiconductor nanostructures with controlled dimension and morphology have initiated great research interest, as it forms the building blocks for the fabrication of photoelectrochemical devices. [7–10] A new class of inorganic–organic hybrid materials have attracted considerable attention due to the mixing of the organic component and inorganic building block. Also, the novel hybrid inorganic-organic composite exhibits a strong quantum confinement effect with a perfectly periodic arrangement, which is based on the [MQ(L)n] laminar structure (where M = Zn, Cd, Mn; Q = S, Se, Te; L = diamine, etc., n = 0.5 or 1). [11] The organic spacers ((L)n) mainly act as a template to connect the inorganic MQ slices (semiconductor materials). Interestingly, the unique structure of inorganic–organic structures is combined through the coordinate bonds. [12] The inorganic–organic hybrid martial shows new electronic structures, excellent conduction pathways toward the electrons, and holes transportation. [13] This enhances the conduction pathway due to multiple/ single layers of semiconductor attached via an organic spacer. Therefore inorganic–organic hybrid martial has attracted the attention of researchers. In previous studies, a family of metal chalcogenide–amine nanostructures such as ([ZnSe](DETA)0.5, ZnSe(en)1/2, etc.) has been widely developed in powder system which requires higher solvothermal/hydrothermal energy to control structural growth. [14–17] Xiong et al. prepared one-dimensional bundles of ZnSe nanowire at 180 °C in a mixed solvothermal route. [18,19]. They studied the influence of water to ethanol amine ratio and reaction temperature effect on morphology. Chen et al. [20] developed various ZnSe·0.5N2H4 hybrid nanostructures at 180 °C by controlling the ratio of hydrazine hydrate to deionized water for photoconversion applications. Recently, different morphologies on Zn foil have been developed through a solvothermal synthesis. ZnSe(en)0.5 on Zn substrate was obtained at 160 °C, and its diverse morphologies were studied by changing the volume ratio of precursors (hydrazine hydrate to diethanolamine) in the solvothermal reaction. [21–23] As far known, some chemical deposition methods such as hydrothermal and/or solvothermal method have been established to synthesize the inorganic-organic hybrid semiconductors but needs a high deposition temperature > 120 °C. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop the inorganic–organic hybrid nanostructure at lower energy. Thus, it is still challenging to synthesize inorganic–organic hybrid nanostructure photoelectrode directly by the solvothermal method at a low growth temperature (80 °C). Therefore, it needs to develop and control the surface morphology as well as crystalline phase of the inorganic–organic hybrid nanostructured photoelectrodes for photoelectrochemical (PEC) hydrogen production applications by precisely controlling the synthetic parameters that affected their nucleation and growth.

However, in the present study, we demonstrated first time the growth and structural organization of inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB on Zn foil substrates via a low temperature (80 °C) solvothermal method by precisely controlling the synthetic conditions like changing precursor concentrations or introducing additional solvents during the process. Additionally, another most important topic in our experiment system, Zn foil itself can directly behave as the reactant precursor and it is beneficial for avoiding the use of supplementary substrate to obtained ZnSe(en)0.5 RB. Firstly, the morphological composition of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB was tuned via different solvothermal reaction times (2, 4, 8, and 12 h). Furthermore, the effect of the growth temperature and precursor concentration on the phase and morphology evolution of the ZnSe(en)0.5 RB electrode have been presented in detail. After the low-temperature (80 °C) solvothermal method, due to Se adsorption, the as-prepared ZnSe(en)0.5 RB inorganic-organic hybrid electrode deposited Zn foil (ZnSe(en)0.5 RB/Zn Foil) exhibits the red-brick color. However, the utilization of visible light in the solar spectrum is still challenging for large bandgap materials including ZnSe(en)0.5 RB. Therefore, nano-scale cation-exchange reactions have been used for the fabrication and tailoring the bandgap of novel nanostructured photoelectrodes for energy as well as environmental applications. [24–26] Wu et al. [14] prepared inorganic-organic ZnSe nanosheets and then, reacted with Cd2+ ions to result in hollow Cd x Zn1−
x Se nanoframes for hydrogen production. Following this principle, in our study, the series of Cd2+ ion exchange of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB was accomplished at different temperatures (140,160, and 180 °C for 18 h), which is attributed to the formation of the dual nanostructured ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP photoelectrode. Furthermore, the optimized ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP photoelectrode synthesized via Cd2+ ion exchange at 160 °C for 18 h exhibited the highest photocurrent density of 13.14 mA·cm−2 at -0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl with hydrogen production of 237.79 μmol·cm−2 for 3 h under one sun illumination. Moreover, the improved PEC performance due to the ZnO NR acts as a UV light absorber as well as conductive channels for the photoelectrons. While porous Zn1-xCdxSe NP attached to the bottom of the ZnO NR near the Zn foil also synergistically contribute charge separation reaction kinetics and elongated recombination lifetime. Furthermore, a detailed charge transfer mechanism in ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 dual nanostructure was proposed. Therefore, this low-temperature synthesis process ultimately provides a new way to the synthesis of inorganic-organic hybrid-based materials with a topmost upgrading in the performance-to-cost ratio in the future.
Zinc foil, selenium powder, sodium sulfide (Sigma Aldrich), sodium sulfite, ethylenediamine, ethanol (Samchun), cadmium nitrate tetrahydrate (Junsei), and were used without any further purification.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Low-temperature solvothermal synthesis of inorganic-organic (ZnSe(en)0.5 RB) hybrid red-brick templates on Zinc foil
ce:section.ce:para: A low temperature-synthesized ZnSe(en)0.5 RB electrode was prepared on Zn foil with the solvothermal method. The detailed experimental process is described as follows: A Zn foil was first polished using sandpaper to achieve a mirror-like surface and the resulting polished foil was kept in ethanol solution followed by ultrasonication for 15 min. Next, a reacting medium was prepared separately by dissolving 0.01 g selenium powder in 15 mL ethylenediamine under strong magnetic stirring for 6 h. Subsequently, the polished Zn foil was placed vertically inside a 20 mL glass vial such that the polished part was fixed towards the glass wall side. Then, 15 mL of the stirred solution was transferred into a glass vial, which was then tightly sealed and placed in an electric oven at 80 °C for 2, 4, 8, and 12 h in a separate set of experiments. After the reaction was completed, the resulting red-brick-colored film was washed several times with distilled water and ethanol. Finally, the obtained film was air-dried. Finally, the prepared samples based on the different solvothermal time were named as ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-2, ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-4, ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-8 and ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12, respectively.

At the modification stage, the obtained ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode was converted into a dual ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP photoelectrode via Cd2+ ion exchange. In the typical synthesis process, 0.1 g of cadmium nitrate was dissolved in 50 mL distilled water. Subsequently, the prepared solution was transferred into a 70 mL Teflon-lined cylindrical, and the inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 film was mounted on the Teflon mounter and immersed into the solution. Further, the Teflon cylinder was placed in a stainless-steel autoclave, which was then sealed and maintained at 140, 160, and 180 °C for 18 h in an electric oven in separate sets. After cooling the autoclave to room temperature, the obtained electrode was washed with distilled water and dried at room temperature. The Cd2+ ion exchanged samples were labeled as ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 140, ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 and ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180, depending on the fabrication temperature.

The morphological structure of the as-prepared photoelectrode was analyzed using high-resolution field emission scanning electron microscopy (HR-FESEM) (SUPRA 40 V P, Carl Zeiss, Germany). The crystal structure was analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 Focus diffraction system with CuKα irradiation). The UV-Vis spectra were measured in the wavelength range of 200–800 nm using a Shimadzu UV-2600 series UV-Vis spectrophotometer. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was carried out using a Paragon 1000 spectrometer (PerkinElmer) for detailed observation of the composition of the as-prepared material. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL ARM-200 F) high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) associated with energy-dispersive X-ray (EDAX) and annular dark-field scanning TEM (ADF-STEM) analysis was performed to understand the microstructure. The TEM analysis samples were scratched from the Zn foil and coated on the Ni grid. A time-resolved photoluminescence spectroscopy (PL) study was performed using a confocal microscope (MicroTime-200, PicoQuant, Germany). Pulsed diode lasers (375 and 470 nm with a pulse width of ∼30 ps) were used as excitation sources, and emission photons were counted using a time-correlated single-photon counting system (PicoHarp300, PicoQuant GmbH, Germany). Steady-state PL spectra with varying excitation laser powers were measured by guiding emission photons from the samples to an attached spectrometer (F-7000, Hitachi). The experimental details have been described in detail elsewhere. [27–29] X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to examine the chemical composition and identify the chemical status of the prepared samples. An equipped monochromatic (PHI Quantera II XPS spectrometry) Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1,486.6 eV) at 200 kV was analyzed to obtain the results.

The photoelectrochemical performance of the ZnSe(en)0.5 RB based photoelectrode was measured using a three-electrode electrochemical cell system. The ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP160 photoelectrode was used as the working electrode (1cm × 1cm), Pt wire as the counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) as the reference electrode. Aqueous-based 0.25 M Na2S + 0.35 M Na2SO3 solution was used as the electrolyte solution. A solar 1.5 G (W xenon lamp 100 mW cm−2) light source was used for irradiation. Electrochemical measurements were performed using a portable potentiostat workstation (COMPACT STAT, Ivium, Netherlands). The photocurrent densities were measured between -1.25 V and 0.1 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed under AM 1.5 G sunlight illumination, with a frequency range of 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz at -0.6 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) with an AC amplitude of 10 mV. The obtained EIS data were fitted using Z View software (Scribner Associates Inc.). Intensity-modulated photocurrent spectroscopy (IMPS) was measured at -0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl under white light (LED 0.4 V) illumination. The applied bias photon-to-current conversion efficiency (ABPE) was calculated using the following equation to understand the photo-response efficiency. [30]
(1) ABPE (%) = J × (1.23-V)/P ×100
where J is photocurrent density under one sun illumination (mA/cm2), V- applied voltage vs. Ag/AgCl, and P- power density of 100 mW cm−2.

The photoelectrochemical hydrogen evolution test was carried out in an especially design three-electrode PEC cell containing photoelectrode as Zn1-xCdxSe-ZnO NR 160, a Pt wire as a counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode. Before testing the PEC hydrogen evolution, the dissolved oxygen was removed from the electrolyte through purging nitrogen (99.9 %) gas for 1 h. Furthermore, the amount of hydrogen evolved at the counter electrode was measured using a gas chromatography (GC) system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (GC-TCD, Agilent 7820, U.S.A.) with a 5Å molecular sieve column.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Structural characterization of the low temperature synthesized inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 red-brick on zinc foil
ce:section.ce:para: The morphology of the inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB sample synthesized at different solvothermal times (2, 4, 8, and 12 h) was characterized using HR-FESEM, as shown in Fig. 1 (a–h). The HR-FESEM results reveal that the agglomerated inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB nanostructures were observed on the top surface of Zn foil during this early stage of 2 h (Fig. 1(a)). However, upon extending the solvothermal process for 4 h, the morphology of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB is changed into nanosheets (Fig. 1(c–d)). Moreover, further increasing the solvothermal time to 8 h, there was no significant change in the ZnSe(en)0.5 RB surface structure (Fig. 1(e–f)). Surprisingly, after solvothermal process at 12 h (Fig. 1(g–h)), the growth of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB was increased with red bricks width of ∼1.5 to 2 μm, and the surface morphology was different from the initial stages (i.e. 2, 4 and 8 h). The different growth under solvothermal conditions is due to the chelation of metal ions with ethylenediamine solvent, which causes the different structures of selenide grains. [31] This implies that Se present in (en)0.5-containing medium starts to react with the surface of Zn foil at a lower solvothermal time. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. S1(a–b), the atomic concentration of Se for the 12 h sample increased as compared to a short deposition time (2 h). The ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 exhibits the sheet (Fig. 1(h)) and mesh-like particles (inset of Fig. 1(g)) network with some particles are agglomerated on the surface of the Zn foil-based electrode. However, it suggests that by extending the solvothermal time, the adsorption and concentration of Se could increase on the surface of Zn foil. The solvothermal synthesis and consecutive fabrication is schematically represented in Scheme S1.

XRD was employed to identify the crystal structures of surface agglomerated ZnSe(en)0.5 RB electrodes prepared at different solvothermal times. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the characteristic diffraction peak at a low angle of 11.27 ° indicates the formation of the inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 material where ZnSe layers may interconnected by bridging en molecules. [32,33] With increasing solvothermal time, the XRD peak intensity of the inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 was slightly increased. The obtained XRD diffraction peaks for ZnSe(en)0.5 are almost similar to the previously reported literature. [34] The additional diffraction peaks observed at 2θ = 23.49 ° and 29.68 ° corresponds to the (100) and (101) planes of metallic Se [JCPDS 01-086-2246]. [35] This suggests that in addition to the ZnSe(en)0.5, Se metal still exists on the surface of the Zn foil-based electrode. Furthermore, to elucidate the chemical structure of inorganic-organic hybrid precursors on Zn foil, FTIR spectra were obtained for ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode. The two peaks at 3236 and 3115 cm−1 correspond to asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations for -NH2 group in Fig. 2(b). These stretching vibration bands are slightly shifted at a lower frequency region due to chemical bonding action between surface atoms of Zn foil and N atoms. [36] The peaks at 1580 and 1021 cm−1 are assigned to -NH2 scissors and wagging vibrations, respectively. As far as CH2 group is concerned, the absorption band at 1355 cm−1 is due to wagging vibration, whereas the peaks at 2933 and 2869 cm−1 are associated with asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations, respectively. The absorption band at 1086 cm−1 corresponds to CN stretching vibrations. [37,38] These results support the formation of inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB during the solvothermal reaction on Zn foil. Furthermore, to get a more clear idea about the inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB and overgrowth particles, the TEM analysis was employed. TEM analyses including HR-TEM were attempted to understand the microstructure of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB synthesized at 80 °C for 12 h. Fig.2(c, d) shows the smooth surface of inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB with a width of 600 nm and its selected area in high resolution. According to the HR-TEM analysis, ZnSe(en)0.5 RB has a lattice spacing of 0.31 nm, which is similar to the high-temperature synthesis of ZnSe(en)0.5. [39] The corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) and element wt% (Fig. S2) results are shown in Fig. 2(e). The EDS spectra of ZnSe(en)0.5 nanosheet indicating the equal wt% of the element than that of the Zn, and Se elements of inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5. Furthermore, to get a clearer idea about the overgrowth particles, the TEM, EDS line scanning analysis was employed. Fig. S3 (a) shows the TEM image of scratched nanoparticles aggregated on the surface of the inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode. Fig. S3(b, c) shows the results of TEM-EDS line-scan analysis employed along a linear path passing through the surface to bulk parts of representative aggregated particles. The line scan spectra clearly show that the Se-content is higher than the Zn, thus verifying the Se covers on the surface of the ZnSe(en)0.5/Zn foil electrode. Additionally, Fig. S3(d) shows the EDS spectra with elemental table obtained for Fig. S3(b), indicating the higher wt% of the Se element than that of the Zn, C, and N elements of inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5. This result suggests that the observed agglomerate particles are Se-rich which are covered on the surface of ZnSe(en)0.5/Zn foil electrode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Optical properties of inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 red-brick on zinc foil
ce:section.ce:para: The optical properties of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB synthesized for various solvothermal times were studied by means of UV-Vis absorption spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. S4(A, B) the absorption edges of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB electrodes are observed at 700–750 nm and the band gaps are in the range of 1.78−1.66 eV, calculated using the Tauc equation. [36] The variation in the bandgap could be attributed to structural growth and adsorption of Se on the surface of Zn foil. [35]

ce:section.ce:section-title: Growth mechanism of inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 red-bricks on zinc foil
ce:section.ce:para:
The reaction mechanism of the low-temperature synthesized inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB on Zn foil is shown in Scheme 1 . At the initial stage of solvothermal reaction, the Zn foil acts as a Zn precursor as well as a substrate. When the Zn foil is immersed in (en)0.5 molecules-containing liquid, it forms [Zn(en)0.5]2+ due to the coordination of (en)0.5 molecules. [40–42] At the same time, reduced Se2− in (en)0.5 reacts with [Zn(en)0.5]2+ and begins forming ZnSe(en)0.5 RB at low temperature. The incomplete formation of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-2 and ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-4, in a short time (2 h) is due to the insufficient reaction of (en)0.5 with the Zn foil. Interestingly, when the solvothermal time increases (12 h) the adsorption of Se increases due to the formation of selenium anions (Red-brick) in the presence strong nucleophilic agent of (en)0.5 . [42]
(2) Zn2+ + (en)0.5 → [Zn(en)0.5]2+
(3) (en)0.5 + Se → Se2−
(4) [Zn(en)0.5]2+ + Se2− + (en)0.5 → ZnSe(en)0.5 RB

As shown in Scheme 1, the formation of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB is initiated for short solvothermal reaction time of 2 h. When the time extends to 12 h, the growth of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB becomes vigorous (Fig.1(g, h)). Therefore, it is concluded that the solvothermal time plays measurable role in chemical formation and control growth of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB. The corresponding digital photograph of the as-prepared electrode at a different solvothermal time variation are shown in Fig. S5. It was demonstrated that the growth of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB is strongly influenced by the solvothermal time. Additionally, due to low-temperature synthesis Se-rich structure is formed on inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5, which led to red-brick color to samples. Thus, we believe that the solvothermal low-temperature method may be causing the Se aggregation on the inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 material.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Influences Cd2+ ion exchange temperature on the inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 red-brick
ce:section.ce:para: A hydrothermal cation exchange strategy was implemented to study the influence of Cd2+ ion exchange on the optimum ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12. Fig. 3 (a–b) shows the top and (c) cross-sectional views of the HR-FESEM images of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160, and those for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 140 and ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180 are presented in Fig. S6. After Cd2+ ion exchange at various temperatures, ZnO NR and porous Zn1-xCdxSe dual nanoarchitecture are separately formed on the Zn foil via hydrothermal. However, the parent inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB structure collapses during hydrothermal cation exchange and becomes porous because (en)0.5 moieties in ZnSe(en)0.5 RB are detached in the presence of water and some Cd2+ ions exchange at Zn2+ sites lead to the formation of Zn1-xCdxSe NP. Therefore, the combination of ZnO NR and Zn1-xCdxSe NP on the same Zn foil presents the ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP porous structure helpful for more light absorption and effective charge generation. The crystalline structure of the dual architecture electrode is examined with XRD in Fig. 3(d). The XRD patterns after Cd2+ ion exchange exhibit three diffraction peaks located at 25.28 °, 41.78 °, and 48.76 ° corresponding to the (002), (110), and (200) planes of hexagonal CdSe, respectively [JCPDS 98-065-9134]. Interestingly, these peaks slightly increase in intensity with elevating the Cd2+ ion exchange temperature from 140 to 180 °C, indicating improved crystallinity. Furthermore, other diffraction peaks are also observed at 2θ = 28.6 °, 28.9 °, and 50.3 ° for the electrode, which correspond to (101) and (111) planes of hexagonal ZnO [JCPDS 00-002-0330]. This explains that after the Cd2+ ion exchange, a new self-assembled ZnO rods form on the surface of Zn foil substrate. [43,44] Additionally, the Cd2+ ion exchange makes the diffraction peak at a low angle (11.27 °) disappear, which confirms the removal of (en)0.5 in the dual architecture of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP photoelectrodes. The changes in morphology and structure, caused by Cd2+ ion exchange is further studied by TEM, HRTEM, and EDS mapping for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode in Fig. 3(e–f). The HRTEM analysis reveals the lattice fringes of 0.31 nm, which can be indexed to the (101) plane of CdSe. [45] The EDS elemental mappings exhibit uniform distributions of Cd and Se. Besides, the lower Zn brightness indicating the maximum number of Zn ions is replaced by the Cd2+ ion exchange process. The absence of N in EDS elemental mapping suggests the formed material is inorganic material without any organic moieties (Fig. S7). Furthermore, the uniform distribution of Zn and O in TEM EDS mapping (Fig. S8 (a–c)) confirms the appearance of self-assembled ZnO NR during the formation of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP photoelectrodes after the Cd2+ ion exchange process. In the next step, to support the inorganic-organic hybrid material transformation into inorganic form, the FTIR analysis of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode was carried out. It can be seen that after Cd2+ ion-exchange the stretching and bending vibration peaks of the amino group are removed in ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode (Fig. S9) as compared to the inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 ((Fig. 2 (b)). These results revealing that the obtained material is transformed into inorganic form. Fig. S10 shows UV-Vis absorption spectra of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP electrodes, it can be seen that the absorbance of all photoelectrode is almost same with the existence bandgap of ∼1.65 eV (Zn1-xCdxSe NP) and ∼3.2 eV (ZnO NR), respectively.

The XPS analysis was carried out to understand the chemical state of Se in the inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 electrode, respectively. Fig. 4 a(i) presents two Zn 2p peaks at 1043.9 (2p1/2) and 1020.9 eV (2p3/2), indicating Zn2+ state in inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB. [46] This slight shift in the Zn 2p3/2, then the typical Zn 2p XPS peak in ZnSe is due to N atoms of (en)0.5 strongly coordinate to Zn2+. [47] However, after the Cd2+ ion exchange, remarkably intense Zn 2p XPS peaks at 1044.38 eV and 1021.11 eV are observed, due to ZnO NR (Zn-O bond) formed during the hydrothermal process in Fig. 4a(ii). [48] Furthermore, Fig. 4b(i) shows the existence of broad Se 3d peak for inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 material. The deconvolution results of Se peaks were carried out to understand the actual state of Se in inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 material. Presence of four BE peaks at around 53.8, 54.6, 55.3, and 57.8 eV, indicate that the existence of different Se states in inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 material. The Se 3d XPS peaks at binding energies of 53.8 and 54.6 eV are attributed to Se 3d5/2 and Se 3d3/2 of inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB, respectively [49] However, the existence of Se 3d XPS peaks at 55.1 eV is due to metallic selenium Se (0) on the surface of the sample. [50] The exitance of XPS peak at 58.6 eV indicates a small amount of SeO2 impurity formed due to partial oxidation of Se near the inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB surface. [50,51] Additionally, the XPS elemental analysis (Table S1) shows that Se content is greater than that of Zn in the inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB, suggests that excessive selenium is present on the surface of the sample. However, the Cd2+ ion exchange causes the Se 3d BE shifted to higher energy (54.3 eV) because ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 are converted into Zn1-xCdxSe NP, in Fig. 4b (ii). And, the dense growth of ZnO NR, compared with Zn1-xCdxSe NP, suppresses Se 3d XPS peak in the dual architecture electrode In Fig. 4c (i), the deconvolution of N 1s XPS spectrum for inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB shows the peak at 398.2, which are associated with bonding between Zn and N. However, the XPS peak at 401.0 and 399.2 are attributed to amine group (-NH- and –NH2) in (en)0.5. [20,46] Furthermore, disappearance of the N1 s in the Cd2+ ion-exchanged sample suggest the removal of (en)0.5 moieties from the inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB, Fig. 4c (ii). As shown in Fig. 4d (ii), the Cd XPS peaks at 405.10 and 411.85 eV is related to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 with Cd2+ oxidation state in ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP dual structure. [52,53] However, the appearance of other peaks (404.15 and 411.10 eV) suggest the presence of Cd(OH)2impurity. [54] The O 1s XPS spectrum for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP dual structure exhibits two components with BEs of 529.6 and 531.68 eV attributable to the lattice oxygen (O2−) ions in ZnO and from surface hydroxide oxygen, which can participate in the formation of Cd(OH)2 (Fig. S11). [55] It is in good accordance with the XRD and TEM results that confirms the inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode are transformed into heterogeneous dual ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP structure through a hydrothermal cation exchange reaction.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Influences of Cd2+ ion exchange temperature on the photoelectrochemical properties of inorganic–organic ZnSe(en)0.5red-bricks
ce:section.ce:para: The photoelectrochemical properties of Cd2+ ion-exchanged ZnSe(en)0.5 RB were studied using a three-electrode system. Prior to selection of best inorganic-organic ZnSe(en)0.5 RB electrode, Cd2+ ion-exchange of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-8, ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12, ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-16 electrodes were carried out at 140 °C for 18 h and their respective results were shown in Fig. S12. After Cd2+ ion-exchange, the ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode shown maximum photocurrent density than the ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-8 and ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-16 electrodes. Furthermore, to study the influences of Cd2+ ion exchange temperature on inorganic–organic red-brick ZnSe(en)0.5-12 electrode, Cd2+ ion-exchange process was carried out at different temperatures (140, 160, and 180 °C) for 18 h. Fig. 5 (a) shows the linear sweep voltammetry of the electrode Cd2+ ion-exchanged at different temperatures (140, 160, and 180 °C) for 18 h. As the Cd2+ ion exchange temperature increases from 140 to 160 °C, the photocurrent density of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP photoelectrode increases from 11.98 to 13.14 mA cm−2. But, when the Cd2+ ion exchange is further elevated up to 180 °C, the photocurrent density rather decreases to 9.82 mA cm−2. The improved photocurrent density at 160 °C is due to the combinational effects of optimum growths of ZnO NR and Zn1-xCdxSe NP, unique porous structure and efficient UV & visible light absorptions by ZnO NR and Zn1-xCdxSe, respectively. The chronoamperometric photocurrent density (j-t) curves were measured at applied potential −0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl under chopped light conditions (i.e., ON/OFF after each 10 s interval). All photoelectrodes in Fig. 5(b) exhibit quick photocurrent responses towards the visible sun illumination and among them, ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode does the strongest performance. Further the comparative photoelectrochemical performances of CdSe and ZnO based heterostructure electrodes are shown in the Table S2. In order to understand charge transfer characteristics, EIS measurements were conducted and results are shown in Fig. 5(c). Generally, the highest semicircle arc signifies a high electrode/electrolyte interface charge transfer barrier, [38] which leads to a lower photoelectrochemical performance. The data obtained using Nyquist plot were fitted using RC-circuit model as shown inset of Fig. 5(c), consisting of one sheet resistance (R0) and two parallel RC circuits in which first subcircuit of resistance R1 and capacitance CPE1 is for the bulk of photoelectrode, and the second subcircuit of R2 and CPE2 related to the interface of photoelectrode/electrolyte. The calculated parameters are listed in Table 1 which directly shows a lower R1 value than R2, indicating that electron transport in the bulk of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP is more active compared with feature at the interface of [ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP]/electrolyte. Likewise, the lowest R2 value (45.60 Ω) for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 among the samples suggests fast hole diffusion kinetics from that electrode to an electrolyte. To clearly understand the enhanced PEC performance of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode, IMPS was applied and electron transit time (τ d) was calculated using the IMPS plots and the formula is given in the literature. [56] As revealed in Fig. 5(d), the curve bent more outwards for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 demonstrates a lower charge recombination rate with fast electron transit of 4.98 ms (shorter τd by 1.4 times than ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180 electrode). Fig. S13 shows the ABPE vs. applied potential plots of the (a) ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 140, (b) ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160, and (c) ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180 photoelectrodes. The ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode shows the remarkable enhancement in ABPE (10.94 %) compared to ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 140 (9.55 %) and ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180 (7.45 %) photoelectrodes, respectively. The enhanced ABPE is due to the unique morphology of porous Zn1-xCdxSe NP and the optimum growth of the ZnO NRs in the ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode. [30] Furthermore, to study the contribution of surface area to the photocurrent density of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP nanostructured photoelectrodes, the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was measured using the three-electrode system by cyclic voltammetry (Fig. S14). It was seen that compared to the ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 140 and ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180 photoelectrodes, the ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode exhibits a larger double-layer capacitance value (1.97 mF. cm−2).

The steady-state PL spectrum of semiconductor nanomaterials provides key information regarding their intraband electronic states and relative occupation of charge carrier recombination pathways through electronic states after photoexcitation. In room-temperature, PL spectrum of ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode, the emissions were mostly observed near the band-edge region with slightly broadened emission spectral width and stretched to a longer wavelength region (Fig. S15). Hence, the photoexcited charge carriers in ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode recombine mostly through band-band transitions, including minor contributions through both shallowly and deeply trapped electronic states. [7,10] When the cation in ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 was exchanged with Cd2+ ions, the PL spectrum was completely changed. After 375 nm laser irradiation, two emission peaks were detected as shown in Fig. 5(e, f); a sharp and strong emission near the band edge at 410 nm and a broadened emission in the red-shifted region at 600 nm. Recalling that the Cd2+ ion exchange process makes two separate nanoarchitectures of ZnO NR and Zn1-xCdxSe NP, these emissions are attributable to direct band-edge recombination and deeply trapped carrier recombination through surface defect states of ZnO NRs, respectively. [56,57] When excited by a 470 nm laser, an emission was observed only at 750 nm, which originated from the band-band transition of Zn1-xCdxSe NPs. A comparative study on cation exchange temperature (160 vs. 180℃) explains that the emission at 600 nm is greatly reduced for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160. This notable result suggests that the surface-trapped recombination is significantly suppressed relative to the band-edge emission when the electrode is fabricated at 160℃.

The charge carrier recombination behavior could be quantified in a time-resolved PL study. Transient PL decays in Fig. 6 (a–i) and PL lifetime parameters in Table 2 demonstrate that when ZnO-Zn1-xCdxSe photoelectrodes were excited by a 375 nm laser, the 410 nm emission exhibited a short lifetime (0.21–6.1 ns) with multiple lifetime components, whereas the 600 nm emission did relatively long lifetimes (0.52–62 ns). Direct band-edge recombination typically shows a fast recombination lifetime owing to the free exciton-exciton collision process. [58,59] Conversely, the red-shifted deeply trapped carriers require a longer time to recombine because of the donor-acceptor pair recombination characteristic. [60–62] Through a careful transient PL decay fitting, it is obtained that ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180 photoelctrode has the recombination lifetime in average of 13 ns (375 nm excitation & 600 nm detection), slightly longer than that of ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 (<τ> = 11 ns). The longer lifetime corresponds with increased contribution of the deeply trapped emissions from ZnO NR in the above steady-state PL. Of course, the lifetimes of two electrodes carry completely different values at different detection wavelengths in comparison with ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode . It is another proof that the ZnSe(en)0.5 RB-12 electrode is transformed into the new phase of ZnO-Zn1-xCdxSe.

Furthermore, we also studied the charge carrier recombination behavior for the red emissions at 750 nm under 470 nm laser excitation. The average lifetime (<τ>) differs as 24 and 0.42 ns for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 and ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180 photoelectrodes, respectively. The difference is due to the different contributions of emissive electronic states. As seen in the inset plot of Fig. 6(i), considerable deeply-trapped states at wavelength > 800 nm for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode are responsible for the elongated PL lifetime. However, ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 180 photoelectrode dramatically suppresses the deeply-trapped states and related PL intensity in this spectral region, which consequently facilitates fast free excitonic recombination near the band-edge. To summarize the steady-state and time-resolved PL studies, the high density of deeply trapped states and the elongation of lifetime might synergistically operate to achieve excellent photoelectrochemical performance and enhance hydrogen production. The long-lived charge carriers in the deeply trapped surface states for ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode were more likely to participate in the hydrogen production reaction. Besides, we have checked the effect of Cd2+ ion exchange (160 °C/18 h) with different Cd amounts (0.025 and 0.3 g), and corresponding photoelectrochemical results are shown in Fig. S16. The ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP photoelectrode preparted at 0.1 g Cd precursor exhibits the maximum photocurrent density of 13.14 mA/cm2 at 0 V vs. Ag/AgCl than the other studied photoelectrodes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photoelectrochemical hydrogen production and charge transfer mechanism in ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode
ce:section.ce:para: The hydrogen production and stability of optimized ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode were investigated at -0.2 vs. Ag/AgCl under one sun illumination. Fig. 7 (a) shows an immediate sharp increase in photocurrent followed by a rapid decrease, when light is illuminated onto the sample. But, a slow decrease was observed in photocurrent after 1 h elapsed under illumination. The decrease in the photocurrent density is due to high charge recombination on Zn1-xCdxSe NP and ZnO NR as well as the photocorrosion of whole photoelectrode. However, it is achieved that hydrogen evolution reaches 237.79 μmol over ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode after 3 h of light irradiation. Furthermore, the long-term stability of the optimized photoelectrode was tasted for the 12 h (Fig. S17).

The possible charge transfer mechanism in ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP160 photoelectrode is presented in Fig. 7(b, c). Owing to the existence of dual nanoarchitecture ZnO NR and Zn1-xCdxSe NP, the photoelectrode simultaneously absorbs UV and visible light. It increases the effective number of photogenerated charge carriers (electron-hole pairs), which contributes to photocurrent generation. To ensure the effectiveness of ZnO NR and Zn1-xCdxSe NP in the working electrode, the photocurrent density was measured under the one sun and visible light (λ ≥ 420 nm UV cut-off filter) irradiation at applied potential -0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl (Fig. S18). When the light with λ ≥ 420 nm reached the photoelectrode, only Zn1-xCdxSe NP was activated and the photoelectrode exhibited the lower photocurrent density of 11.03 mA∙cm2 than that under one sun illumination (13.14 mA∙cm−2). In addition to absorbing UV light, ZnO NR plays another role in the photoelectrochemical reaction, boosting the photo-generated charge transfer through a combination with Zn1-xCdxSe. Upon illumination with one sun, photogenerated electrons travel directly through ZnO NR to Zn foil, and thus, it acts as a conductive pathway for photoelectrons. At the same time, holes are generated on the surface of the electrode and react with S2 2− and S2O3 2−. [63] On the other hand, Zn1-xCdxSe NP residing near the base of ZnO NR also contributes to generation of photoelectric charges and their separation through visible light absorption. Favorable band positions of two nanoarchitectures enable the photogenerated charges to transfer from Zn1-xCdxSe NP to the bottom end of ZnO NR. [53] Finally, the photoelectrons move into a Pt counter electrode to produce hydrogen. The accumulated holes at the interface between photoelectrode surface and electrolyte make SO3 2−/S2− and form S2 2− and S2O3 2− in the presence of an aqueous-based Na2S/Na2SO3 electrolyte. [64] From a physico-structural viewpoint, the porous structure of Zn1-xCdxSe NP provides a sufficient active surface area and offers the more active surface site for PEC, which allows an electrolyte to make the most contact with the electrode materials and leads to more charge separation in the photoelectrode. However, the porous structure improves the light absorption properties and provides the multiple pathways photogenerated charge process. [65] Non-uniform ZnO NR and porous Zn1-xCdxSe NP facilitate multiple scattering and absorption of incident light, which helps to generate more charge carriers beneficial to photoelectrochemical reaction. Therefore, the improved charge transportation with combined dual nanoarchitecture is advantageous and presents a new approach toward PEC hydrogen as an eco-friendly fuel.

In summary, we have developed a novel inorganic-organic hybrid ZnSe(en)0.5 RB via a low-temperature solvothermal approach on Zn foil substrate, which is simple and cost-effective. The XRD and FTIR results confirm that as-synthesized material has the chemical structure of ZnSe(en)0.5 in inorganic-organic layered hybrid. The growth and mechanism for ZnSe(en)0.5 RB synthesis is presented through structural and morphological analysis. The existence of Si-rich red-brick hybrid nanoparticles on Zn foil is revealed by using XPS, HRTEM and EDS. When Cd2+ ion-exchanged into ZnSe(en)0.5 RB, the resulting optimum electrode, ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 achieves the highest photocurrent density of 13.41 mA·cm−2 at an applied potential -0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The improved photoelectrochemical performance is attributed to high light-harvesting (UV and visible light), reduced charge recombination, and elongated PL lifetime. In addition, owing to the favorable band positions of ZnO NR and Zn1-xCdxSe NP as well as geometrical coordination between two nanoarchitectures, ZnO NR-Zn1-xCdxSe NP 160 photoelectrode easily transfers an electron, resulting in 237.79 μmol·cm−2 hydrogen evolution under one sun illumination. Therefore, the low-temperature solvothermal synthesis offers an alternate new route for the preparation of inorganic-organic hybrid material, which can be used for developing high-performance photoelectrodes in PEC hydrogen generation.
